div_role=\"menu\":
The issue with the code snippet is that the ARIA role "menu" requires child roles such as "menuitem" or "menuitemcheckbox" to ensure accessibility. The correct version of the code snippet should include the appropriate child roles, like this:

<`div` `aria-labelledby`="..." `role`="menu">
  <`div` `role`="menuitem">Item 1</`div`>
  <`div` `role`="menuitem">Item 2</`div`>
  <`div` `role`="menuitem">Item 3</`div`>
</`div`>
tr_role=\"row\": Issue: The `tr` element has been given a `role` attribute of "row", but it does not contain any child elements with the required ARIA roles. Correct code snippet: Cell 1 Cell 2 Cell 3 Explanation: In order to properly define a table row with ARIA, the `tr` element should have a `role` attribute of "row" and each child `td` element should have a `role` attribute of "cell". This helps screen readers and other assistive technologies to properly identify and navigate the table structure.
ng-select_role=\"listbox\":
The issue with the code snippet is that the ARIA role "listbox" requires the child role "option" to be present. Without the "option" role, the listbox will not be properly accessible to users with assistive technology.

The correct version of the code snippet should include the "option" role as follows:

<ng-select aria-label="..." role="listbox" tabindex="-1">
  <ng-option role="option" value="option1">Option 1</ng-option>
  <ng-option role="option" value="option2">Option 2</ng-option>
  <ng-option role="option" value="option3">Option 3</ng-option>
</ng-select>
